demand.translation[0].definitions[0].def: the need or desire that people have for particular goods and services
demand.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Production is increasing faster than demand.
As a speaker he was always in demand.
demand.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a very firm request for something that you believe you have the right to get
demand.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: demonstrations in support of the nationalists’ demands
demand.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: Demand for housing is higher than ever.
Recently the demand for new cars has been relatively low.
There’s always a big demand for photographs of celebrities.
There is a huge demand for business software and services.
One of the problems is the growing demand for housing.
Consumer demand for new technology is strong.
There are reports that the company cannot produce enough to meet demand.
Public funding for higher education has not kept up with demand.
The existing services were not capable of coping with the demand for advice.
A very hard winter boosted the demand for natural gas.
Higher interest rates reduce the demand for credit.
Demand for energy has continued to rise.
Demand for the products has fallen in the last six months.
Fuel-efficient cars are now much in demand.
In the 1980s, the supply of grain far exceeded the demand.
Many factories closed through lack of demand.
There’s often a surge in demand for the Internet at the weekend.
demand.translation[1].definitions[0].def: to ask for something very firmly, especially because you think you have a right to do this
demand.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: Angry demonstrators demanded the resignation of two senior officials.
‘Where are you going?’ she demanded angrily.
I demand to know what’s going on.
They demanded that the military government free all political prisoners.
It seemed that no matter what she did, more was demanded of her.
demand.translation[1].definitions[1].def: if one thing demands another, it needs that thing in order to happen or be done successfully
demand.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: Too many things demanded his attention at the same time.
It’s a desperate situation demanding a desperate remedy.
demand.translation[1].note_box[0].items[: She demanded to see the manager
In everyday English, you demand that someone does something
In formal English, you demand that someone do something, using the base form of the verb  (=the infinitive without ‘to’)
His opponents are demanding that he resign
You use the base form of the verb when talking about the past  In everyday English, people also say
You demand that someone should do something  This pattern is often used in the past, when reporting what someone has demanded
His opponents demanded that he should resign
demand.translation[2].definitions[0].def: the amount of spending on goods and services by companies and people in a particular economy
demand.translation[2].definitions[0].exa: Demand in the US economy generated 23 million new jobs during the 1990s.
demand.translation[2].definitions[1].def: the total amount of a type of goods or services that people or companies buy in a particular period of time
demand.translation[2].definitions[1].exa: Lower interest rates did nothing to increase demand for loans to buy houses.
There was a very strong demand for jeans and T-shirts over the last month.
Chrysler said its Jeep plant won’t operate next week because of weak demand.
demand.translation[2].definitions[2].def: the total amount of a type of goods or services that people or companies would buy if they were available
demand.translation[2].definitions[2].exa: Power companies have been forced to reduce voltage when demand exceeded available supplies during extreme cold or hot spells.
Demand for phone service in Thailand far outstrips the supply with back orders totaling about one million.
demand.translation[2].definitions[3].def: the idea that the more something costs, the less demand for it there is
